Dear Sir*
1. Ctoe of the fortunate results of the Congress on Opera in Radio,
TV and Film which was held at Salzburg in August 195&, within the framework
of the Festival, was the decision of the City of Salzburg to award an Opera
Prize. The purpose of this Prize is to ehoowxage the. creation of ope ratio
works’conoeived primirily in terms of TV but adaptable, aesthetically and
economically, to the modern operatic stage. The TV studios of a number of
countries are producing works which they will have commissioned especially
for this occasion and the international Jury which will meet in Salzburg in-^
August 1959 to award the Prize will base its judgment not only on the score
and the text but also on a telerecorded production of each work submitted.
2, To mark the award of the Salzburg Opera *rize, a second Congress
will be held in the Kongresshaus, Salzburg, from Sunday 23rd to Saturday 29th
August 1959. It will be devoted to "Opera and Ballet in TV and Film and
^ill be organized by the TV Service of Austrian Radio (Osterreichischer
Rundfunk) and the International Music Council,
As you will see from the draft programme attached, the 1959 Congress
will give participants the opportunity of comparing methods used by the TV
and film producers of many countries in presenting opera and ballet (includ¬
ing, in the case of the former, classical operetta and, in the case of the
latter, the classical dances of oriental countries). Illustrations will be
given of the various degrees in the adaptability of a stage-work to TV,
including t
a) relay of a normal performance from a theatre;
b) relay of a stage performance specially prepared for TV purposes;
c) stage production transferred to a TV studio;
d) TV production of a work written for the stage;
e) TV production of a work conceived for the medium.
Wherever possible, examples will be taken from different productions of the
same scenes and comments invited from stage and TV producers concerned.
Particular consideration will be given to the following questions!
a) the suitability of existing works for TV and the creation of new forms
of entertainment (incorporating opera, dance, mime, etc..) peculiar to TV,
b) artistic and technical problems raised by dubbing, playbaok, ghosting,
synchronization and similar procedures,
d) cooperation between music schools and TV in the training of stage
artists in TV technique.
Mr. Burton PAULO
Bramley Cottage
links Road BBAMLST Surrey
